text:
Stop going to the academia just for david when there's one for free if you're in a pinch choose uffizzi over accademia!

Edit.
I think a point a lot of you are missing is the fact I said in a pinch, this is a solution for people who are wanting to see a lot of art but don't have a lot of time or a specific interest in sculptures.
If you loveआणखी sculptures and casts you'll love the Accademia.
If you don't have a lot of time you want to see a mix of both paintings, famous paintings at that, you have a chance to see Leonardos, and of sculptures, because they do have a vast collection of statues too, the Uffizi is the best choice.
I'm also saying this because a lot of people just go in for the David maybe realize that there's another couple Michelangelos but they are there for the David and then they kind of leave, I understand being in a rush but at that point you're wasting your money and time.

comments.comment_text: The statues of David outside in the piazzas are replicas only, not the original. You must go to the Accademia if you want to see the real David carved by Michelangelo.

Those arent the originals….they
are replicas. The Academia is definitely worth the trip!
Not everyone wants to see a ton of art. Going to the Academia makes sense in this case. Especially if you are short on time.
Seeing David in person took my breath away. Had been waiting to see him since I studied History of Art in college. Worth the 40 year wait.

I think a point a lot of you are missing is the fact I said in a pinch, this is a solution for people who are wanting to see a lot of art but don't have a lot of time or a specific interest in sculptures.
If you love sculptures and casts you'll love the Accademia.
If you don't have a lot of time you want to see a mix of both paintings, famous paintings at that, you have a chance to see Leonardos, and of sculptures, because they do have a vast collection of statues too, the Uffizi is the best choice.
I'm also saying this because a lot of people just go in for the David maybe realize that there's another couple Michelangelos but they are there for the David and then they kind of leave, I understand being in a rush but at that point you're wasting your money and time.
There's a big difference if you're actually interested in Michelangelo.

I think that unless people are fairly interested in art, they should skip the Uffizi if they are short on time. It is huge and overwhelming unless you have some knowledge and a lot of interest. The Academia takes much less time, and seeing the original David is impressive for most people. If you are just going to look at a replica, you might as well skip the trip and look at photos on the internet!
Thanks for the tip….I still want to go to Accademia 😊
Michelangelo, one of the world's most famous Gay artists.
Don't go to Paris to see the Eiffel tower when there's one in Las Vegas!

My husband, who is not much of an art aficionado, reallllllly appreciated seeing the original David. It was his fav part of visiting Florence, which honestly surprised me... in a good way. We skipped the Uffizi, even though I love La Primavera. (I had studied art in Florence, so personally have seen it all many times.)

This is bad advice; I don’t care if she is an “art history student.” How many copies of Rodin’s “Thinker” do you suspect there are? Besides, some of my favorite Michelangelo’s are the emerging slaves in the gallery in front of the David.
You can't compare the replica David to the original. The original is stunning and a must see if you're there.

text: Hello I am looking to fly to Italy and carry a small personal item bag with me. On the way back I want to check a bag. I would like to buy the luggage bag in Italy to bring back wine olive oil and basalmic vinegar. What would be equivalent to a Walmart over there to buy cheap luggage?

comments.comment_text: Any shop or street vendor, they are everywhere
You can buy one on the street( souvenir) that's what i do.
Those things require special packaging it is better to have a specialist do. Gets a box with a handle.
You can find suitcases at a common store Scarpamond it s called Shoe World I’m Italian. Think DSW shoe.

Any of the shops/
merchants that you buy from will typically ship your purchases anywhere in the world. An easy and simple solution.

Here is what we use. We’ve used both the bubble wrap and air types. Both work fine. We almost always bring back something liquid. Usually wine. We have never had a bottle break…. We just put them in our luggage and pad with our clothes.
They are all over the streets and not that expensive

I would buy a hard sided checked suitcase and use Wine Angels(Amazon).
We brought back wine, olive oil, vinegar & honey. Everyhing was intact when we got home.
Buy at any of the flea markets. Bring wine envelops for your oil and balsamic , plus extra bubble wrap & tape. I do it all the time.

My experience doing this wasn’t great. I found most of the places we had access to were very expensive (tourist traps) and the suitcase was actually garbage making it difficult to navigate to the airport. Can you take something with you? foldable duffle with you to use as a carryon on the return trip and use your original carryon to check?
Chinese shop or Globo
I bought 1 at the markets. I think I paid 25€.
Monoprix
I remember bringing back wine from France in my checked bag. It was really special when it burst open.
There were plenty of small carry on bags for sale reasonably priced when I was there last month in the outdoor market area.
Go on their equivalent of Marketplace and buy used.

If you can check a bag at no charge going over, just check an empty one that your carry on will fit into. You can merge them till you need to use them. Also, pack empty amazon used bubble bags in the empty suitcase and maybe some smaller boxes. I have used them to pack breakables. I also pack a small roll of packing tape. Anything I don’t need I can trash.
I always take a roll of bubble wrap it's lightweight takes hardly any room and you can use it for allsorts of fragile purchases.

Do what my best friend does. She packs a suitcase and then fits it into an empty suitcase, to fill up on her return.
You’ll save money and space on the second suitcase.
Isn’t she a genius ?
Why don't you just take one over empty if you already have one. Check it in. Done.
Thank you for all the responses!!!
I really like the idea of bring the carry on with me with the stuff I would need in it to protect my wine. Can I keep it locked up at the train station till I need it? What would that cost?

We ended up checking our carry on on the way back and put some stuff in a duffel I had brought with us to use as a carry on. The wine was in that checked bag, cushioned by our clothes, in vaccuum bags just in case of breakage.
I think “wine,” “vinegar,” and “cheap suitcase” don’t belong together. It sounds like a recipe for regret.

Use sturdy checked bag on way there plus bring an extra packable/ fold up backpack to put your clothes into as a carry on for the plane ride on the way back. Use your study checked suitcase for your purchases.
I would pack a duffle in your suitcase. Pack your oil and liquids well in your suitcase and the duffle with your clothes..shoes etc . I've done several times with no breakage
Following

We only used carryon luggage but did shopping for gifts while there. We bought a good size tapestry bag from a street vendor, put dirty clothes in it and put our souvenirs in our carryons to bring them home and put the dirty clothes in the new bag. Worked out great.
Florence has outside second hand sales -- you could check when they are...
I purchased a cheap bag for $65 , the shops are all over, I also shipped olive oil and got screwed, told me it would be $59, got back home and sent me an invoice for $300 more!
Dependant where you are going.you can buy luggage in many little souvenir shops in Rome, what do you think is cheap? We have also bought stuff from globo as well.
Dependat where you are going . You can buy luggage in many little souvenir shops in rome what do you think is cheap we have also bought

Not sure about Walmart quality but here in Italy most of us buy cheap luggage in chinese-owned shops ("dai cinesi"). If you want a slight better quality look for shops such as Carpisa, Scarpe & Scarpe etc but most banally even Primark in Milan Center is ok (or other chains like Tedi, Kik, Action etc)
Chinese shops, they are everywhere. And yes, we have bought good quality luggage in such shops.

I’d like to just take the trains, but they don’t have a lot of returning trains listed online right now. Do they post more as it gets closer, or are they just that limited? I figured we’d go from Rome to Naples and Naples to Pompeii and back. I’ve seen guided tour options but they seem to be buses and I’d like to avoid that if possible. TIA 🙂

From Naples take the circumvesuviana
train either from Porta Nolana or Garibaldi. Although I recommend porta nolana, less crowded. You get off at Pompei cross the street and you are at the entrance. I recommend to have the full day for Pompei and get the audio guide.

Yes travel by train, check returning times when you get there and don't be late. Pompei is just wonderful. I've been 4 times each for 7 hours and would go back there in a heart beat. Just grab a tour book and off you go, no need to go with a tour.

Take frecciarossa from Rome termini to napoli centrale. Then go down stairs and take three circumvesuviano
train and get off at pompei scavi stop.

I suggest you book with the trainline app.

According to a google search, here are a few ways to get from Rome to Pompeii by train. You can take a direct train from Rome Termini to Pompeii Scavi station, which is the closest train station to the ruins of Pompeii. This train is only available on Sundays from July to October, and there is only one train per day. The journey time is about 2 hours and 15 minutes.

If you are not traveling on a Sunday, you can take a train from Rome Termini to Napoli Centrale station in Naples. From there, you can take a regional train to Pompeii Scavi station. The journey time from Rome Termini to Napoli Centrale is about 1 hour, and the journey time from Napoli Centrale to Pompeii Scavi is about 30 minutes.

There are many trains available from Rome Termini to Napoli Centrale, so you should be able to find a train that fits your schedule. The regional trains from Napoli Centrale to Pompeii Scavi are less frequent, but you should still be able to find a train that works for you.

I checked the train schedules for October, and there are a few returning trains listed from Pompeii Scavi to Rome Termini. The number of returning trains will probably increase as it gets closer to October.

If you are not comfortable taking the train, you can also take a guided tour to Pompeii from Rome. There are many different tour companies that offer guided tours to Pompeii, and some of them even offer transportation from Rome to Pompeii.

Here are some tips for taking a day trip to Pompeii from Rome by train:

* Book your train tickets in advance, especially if you are traveling on a Sunday.
* Allow plenty of time for travel, especially if you are taking the train from Rome Termini to Napoli Centrale and then the regional train to Pompeii Scavi.
* Wear comfortable shoes, as you will be doing a lot of walking at Pompeii.
* Bring sunscreen and a hat, as it can be hot in Pompeii in October.
* Pack a water bottle, as there are no water fountains at Pompeii.
* Be prepared to wait in line, as Pompeii can be very crowded, especially in October.

I hope this helps!

I randomly picked 10/17 and there's at least one return train every hour until 9:00pm. Try Google Maps, and switch from car to train and it will let you choose date and time and show the options within that hour.
We are doing that now and by trains
I have just booked a tour from Rome to pompei found that a better alternative as it includes train, bus lunch and other places to visit.

text: To see the ruins of Pompei which ticket should I buy? I want to see the ruins and Mt. Vesuvius in one day. And should I go to Herculaneum as well?

I recommend not doingPompei and Herculaneum in the same day.
Expectation and reality it’s completely different story

You will not enjoy yourself if you try to do two, much less three in one day.
Pompeii is an all day experience if you include eating an transport.
I did Pompei and Vesuvius in one day but do not recommend to do the same. You can do Vesuvius and Herculaneum in one day and Pompei another day.
Are there plenty of trains returning to Naples if we train to Herculaneum? Seem plenty going down but not sure about returning.
Way to much in 1 day

You should visit Herculaneum as it is much better persevered. The beach bath there is amazing. Opalants is the most amazing of the three sites. If I only could go to one it would be opalants as is is perfectly preserved and was a royal residence on the beach with an Olympic size swimming pool! If you you to Pompeii don’t miss the house of mysteries. It is outside of the town going north from the marina gate on the old Roman road.

We’ve done Pompeii a couple of times. ￼
It is not the kind of place you just run through. If you do that, and you’ll miss the point all together!!

Each time we’ve gone (fall and spring), the crowds were massive, squeezing into houses or points of interest, which are indeed with the 2-5 minute wait to walk into some of them.

Our day at Pompeii last year was basically a morning train from Naples to Ercolano, then we walked to the entrance. Did the morning and mid day in Pompeii and then took the train back to Naples for a late lunch. By the time our lunch (pizzas) and coffees concluded it was 4 PM, which was perfect. Had zero energy or interest to do anything else before dinner time.
The sun was brutal and draining… umbrellas and hats were almost pointless so be prepared if it’s warm when you go (bring drinking water!!!)

We found the most amazing lil room at a place called Francos Villa, it was right down the street from Pompeii, the family made an amazing authentic Italian dinner for all the guests and they had a pool and we woke up to a delicious breakfast, it was the best meals we had in all of Italy. We walked to Pompeii and spent the day there then went to herculeum and headed to sorrento and Capri for a cpl nights. On our way back we found another family owned lil hotel right on Mt vesuvius, we woke up and they made a big breakfast with the most amazing view, and hiked vesuvius before heading back to Rome. Those 2 small family hotels were the best stays in all of Italy. We didn't plan those stays ahead of time, because of the weather we had to leave Rome a day early so we just found it online on our way driving to Pompeii.

I think it depends on how much of Pompeii you want to see. I don’t think I’d be able to spend more than 3 hours there and don’t want to take a tour.

We’re planning to take the first train from sorrento to Pompeii, take the bus up to mt Vesuvius, do the hike, take the bus back to Pompeii. Explore Pompeii. Depending on how long we spend in Pompeii, we’ll either take the train back to sorrento or take it up to Herculaneum and then the last train back to sorrento. Planning for lunch in Pompeii and dinner in either Herculaneum or sorrento!

The Rome to rio app has been helpful to gather train times!
Much prefer Herculaneum to Pompeii it’s smaller so easier to navigate and much better preserved it would be way to much to try and do all 3 even2 will be a push
Guided tour 41 € fo person, without 21€, about Pompeii ruins.

text:
Beauty of Rome 🤩
#romeitaly

Planning a trip for my daughter's High school graduation gift. She wants to do authentic not touristy. She's a foodie and loves coffee. Recommendations. This will be her first trip out of the country. Planning on 2 weeks.

comments.comment_text: Puglia

Italy is a hard place to avoid tourists. I’d either focus on smaller cities, or go to the south, and if possible go in May.
My favourite thing about Italy is going to food markets and using the local ingredients. If she likes the idea of this, then get somewhere with a kitchen.
You can also specifically google food routes of Italy. There’s a UK paper called The Guardian and they have really good travel articles.
Puglia
Check out Bologna. There are tourists, but it’s not as popular a destination as other cities. There are lots of foodie tours, but I just watched a lot of videos and chose places that looked good.

This place in Rome has the best espresso. A local told us to try it out. It was so delicious.

https://
caffesanteustach
io.com/
It depends. Would she rather visit museums and churches or go to sea cities?
BTW indeed avoid places full of tourists look for the restaurant up the mountain or in quit places and ask locals where they eat

Winter is when to avoid tourists. Since she’s in High School it would be a good idea to get her involved in the planing and researching what her interests are. People are online so much anyway, include her in the research of places.
Bologna 👍🏻
you can have authentic experiences in every city, even the most touristic ones. the important thing is choose the right places where eat and not those made only for tourists.

Cooking school at Casa Gregorio in a beautiful little hill top town between Rome and Milan. Not touristy at all. Daily cooking and food related field trips. Amazing coffee/
cappuccino/
espresso machine in common room of villa for any time of day coffee breaks. Check out their website. Can often find a good sale. One of our favorite trips of all time!

Stay in a city/town you've never heard of to avoid tourists - make sure it has a train station. Take the train to Rome during the day - and return for dinner to your place. To go to Italy the first time and not-see the historical "touristy" sites will be a regret if she doesn't get to return.

If it’s her first time I think she should at least experience a bit of Rome and Venice in spite of the crowds. After that I’d look at small towns or villages. The towns of the Veneto are great plus they’re near Venice.

Everyone loves to be near the sea but if you don’t want touristy crowds I’d avoid both the Cinque Terre and the Amalfi Coast. The town of Camogli is a very pretty seaside village that provides a more authentic experience. There will be other visitors there, yes, but mostly those visitors will be Italians.

Tuscany is high on the radar of most tourists but if you want uncrowded snd suthentic I’d look into the still beautiful but less visited Tuscan towns. Pitligliano and Massa Marittima are both wonderful but are more authentic places. We’ve actually been the only foreigners in them on a few occasions.

You’re in for a treat no matter where you go!
If you want to spend one week doing an authentic Italian small group tour check out the Bluone website. I have done all of these tours and they are truly fantastic.

Out of which country?
Btw, an Italian opinion. The 2 cities with the best coffee tradition in Italy are certainly Trieste and Napoli. Compaired to these two cities, every other espresso in Italy kind of sucks.
I would suggest a trip from Trieste to Napoli. You would pass in different parts of the country, most of them non touristic, but it would be a very interesting trip.
I would personally do 2 days in Trieste, one/two in Venice if you want to, one/two in Padua, two in Bologna, three/four around Perugia (Spoleto and Assisi, all these cities are small and close to each other).
And the end in Napoli. You can also visit the wonderful island of Procida.
All these places are wonderful. Extremely beautiful. There is a lot of beautiful countryside too, and you would avoid all the tourists for the main part. Food is great and compared to the main tourist spots it would be cheap and more authentic imo. I would actually do this trip myself.
Also, all of this is very feasible by train.

Florence can be touristy but it was really beautiful and my favorite from where we went. It is a popular city but didn’t feel very touristy at all. Rome felt way too touristy to us. As well as Positano. Florence didn’t feel that way to us

When in Rome, we always stay in a place called Hotel Golden. It’s in a neighborhood, out of the way, near Villa Borghese. It’s a walk, but we love it! The neighborhood is quiet, there are few tourists, and restaurants are great. Run by a family, who always give us fantastic suggestions.
Florence is amazing! Maybe somewhere a lot of tourists don't go? We loved Genoa so much we are coming back next year and spend 10 days there. People also say to skip Milan but it is amazing as well.
Every place in Italy has a different food and a different wine, not even we Italians know the infinite specialties of our country. You can choose to visit the small villages (Tuscany for example)
Let her do her own research and suggest the excursions. Then you decide. It’s your trip too.
Italy!
Umbria and Tuscany have many authentic towns with low tourism, along with great food, abundant history, and views unlimited

I just took my granddaughter on a graduation trip end of May/first part of June. We were gone about 16 days. We spent 3 full days Rome then trained to Venice for 3 full days. Train to Florence for 2 full days then flew to Paris for 3 full days. I did not count the days we traveled. She loved the trip. We didn’t try to do too much. Only the most major sights. We shopped, ate fabulous food, drank delicious coffee, indulged in gelato, strolled. ♥️

I just came back from time in the Piedmont region. The food was incredible. Our time was spent visiting small towns and exploring restaurants and wineries and small farms making incredible cheese and other lovely, gourmet products. It was truly delightful and not overrun with tourists. We stayed in the region around Acqui Terme. I would highly recommend staying at an agriturismo and visiting small villages like Cessole, Bubbio and Barolo, and larger towns/cities like Alba. A really magical experience.

I don’t think you can skip Rome, first coffee in the airport with fresh brioche… 😋 The city is beautiful and the food is Amazing. I would visit the hills around the city and then go to Naples, best coffee, pastries and pizza! Beautiful city to visit.
Not sure if you want to do the Amalfi Coast or go up North. Visit Umbria, Tuscany, Bologna, Milan…Venice…Ju
st stop in random towns , you will be surprised by how every towns has something different to offer, food, churches, beautiful views… Have fun!
PLEASE don’t let her miss Florence and Rome!

text:

text: What is the differences/advantages booking train tickets directly on train site vs Omni/Rome2Rio?

comments.comment_text: I used Trainline for 13 trips in Italy. I loved that it included all trips from both companies. Kept all tickets in chronological order, QR codes, you can also check final destination and changes are clear.

If you buy a ticket from Trenitalia for instance and there is a problem with the trip, they will know about the problem and will immediately be able to help you with an alternative option or a refund. The other sites are 3rd party sites, they don't know and don't particularly care about the fact that there is a problem and you need a refund immediately or an alternative travel option.

I see zero advantages to booking on a website unless you can still access the booking and tickets easily by phone. I swear by trainline myself though have used omio before for other transport. Plus the apps give price point differences among multiple carriers.
Gayla Faye Bell
I used Rome 2 Río and Omio and had no issues with either one.
Third party sites charge additional fees so you will pay more for the same ticket.
After using all I found Omio the ‘go to site’ - easy to use and gives all travel options between your required routes

text: My friends and I are going to Italy on September 7 for two weeks. We have everything booked except for our return from Siena to Rome. Our options are to hire a driver (much more expensive) or take the train. It appears that we need to go from Siena to Florence to Rome. We have pre booked our other train rides but I am thinking we could just buy our tickets on each train station. Any advice or suggestions would be welcome.

comments.comment_text: You can surely get between those places pretty easily by train and most likely do not need to book in advance if your timing is flexible. Download the Trenitalia app and the Italo app(nicer more business style trains) and just keep an eye on the schedules on the apps to make sure you don’t have to wait around or rush.

If it's regionale or regionale veloce trains, you can book/buy tickets up to half an hour before the trip.
If it's frecciarossa/
frecciargento/
italo (private alternatives to freccia) it's like with plane tickets, the sooner the better
You can go from Siena to Rome. Just go to Orvieto then change to Rome.
Buy as you go as delays are common.
Use Rome2Rio and input your two destinations. It gives you all the options to go from A to B.
We have done this several times. Local train from Siena to Florence and then the fast train to Rome. Book the fast train in advance if you want, but not necessary.

comments.comment_text: Marche, Numana, look for 'spiaggia della due sorelle' , through 'passo del lupo' for hiking and best views of the see. Enjoy🤗

I love the Marche and there are so many great towns, both on the coast and inland. Driving between them you will see wonderful views. Ascoli Piceno is one of the larger towns. I recently saw a promotion for a festival going on there now (mid-August) for the delicious local specialty of stuffed olives, called olive Ascolane. Fabriano is another lovely town with an interesting museum about the local production of paper. A not-to-miss hilltown is Urbino, which has a fabulous Ducal palace to visit and the views are great. San Benedetto del Tronto is a seaside town where we had amazing seafood. While I have not been to any wineries there, there is a fantastic white, Verdicchio, produced in the area around Jesi. The region is incredibly varied geographically,
with beaches and mountains and lots of small charming towns—and most are far less crowded than other regions.
Recanati, Grotte di Frasassi (a must!), Valadier's temple of Frasassi, Monti Sibillini

Roughly what sort of times do the Qantas crew serve meals?

comments.comment_text: What time of day are you leaving?
So,,, I flew perth to Venice, stop over in Dubai, we left at 11pm, they served food approx 1 hr into service, then breakfast approx 2hr prior to landing, this was 11hr flight
by service I meant flight.
are you doing a direct flight?
Following as I am doing the reverse direct flight

What time do you leave? Generally "dinner" then another meal before you land "breakfast" maybe. It's fine to refuse meals to keep your body's equilibrium....
had to do that from Sydney to Dubai as we'd just been fed Auckland to Sydney. I set my watch to the destination time when I leave even though I will try and sleep. Have fun in Italy
Following as l am doing the reverse direct Flight
What date?
I did the 16hr early this week. Left Perth 22:50 and dinner was within an hour. They then offered snacks all night - endless snacks. Breakfast was a 2hrs before we landed.
Get the app timeshifter, it tells you when to sleep and when to have caffeine to reduce jet lag. I flew 13hrs + 6hrs to get to Rome from SA and I didn't get any jet-lag!
Following! We are also flying Qantas to London

My girls just did this flight plus connection to Sydney and they found the trip back from Italy much easier than on the way there.
They were offered limited water bottles on way there which was very frustrating but they said plenty of food.

We did this flight last week Perth to Rome Qantas. Dinner about an hour after takeoff, we were a bit delayed so around 12.30 am. Then snack service as required, everyone seemed to sleep for various durations of course. Breakfast about 2hours before landing. Landed and stayed awake all day in Rome. Hope this helps.
F

We are doing the same flight in 5 weeks. Dinner usually served after about an hour into flight. Try to get to sleep as soon as possible after dinner. Then breakfast is served about 2 hours out of Dubai. Enjoy ! 😊
I did that flight last year. Dinner almost straight away and breakfast 2 hours before landing. Snacks available all night.
What time are you leaving?
We downloaded time shifter app to plan our sleep schedule for flight

We were told one of the carriers adjusts to the local time as soon as your on, can’t recall which one though 😂 thinking emirates over Qantas at the moment but not sure, we’re going next year from perth as well so everything helps 👍

I’ve always found it always depends on what time you arrive at destination re jet lag. I always look for flights that arrive mid to late afternoon or early evening. Morning arrivals are terrible for jet lag. Also unless I break the return flight for a day or two, say Singapore, or HK,I find jet lag much worse on the return trip.
Time shifter is an excellent app to use to minimise jet lag.

It's about two/ two and half hours after taking off from Perth, you will have snacks that you can get throughout the night (self serve) and then again the meal I think it's about 3 hours from landing.

Good luck 🤞
Never slept the whole flight to Italy ,just cant with such discomfort in those seats !
Hope you do

text: We will be traveling to Italy next year with our 13, almost 14 year old son. We were hoping to do some e-bike tours in various cities. However, I have read that Italy requires e-bike riders to be 14 years old. Does anyone know how strict they are regarding the age limit when renting e-bikes/touring?

I just got back from 9 days in Italy. First trip there, and it was amazing. 3 days in Rome, 3+ days at The International Kitchen cooking school at Il Falconiere outside of Cortona, 2 nights in Florence, 1 night in Venice. I don’t often post in groups, but I asked for and got recommendations for jewelry, and I took in a lot of helpful info during my planning (I planned/booked the whole trip myself). There are a few things to note from my experience that may help others:
1- we used more euros than planned. Little purchases like gelato, cheese and crackers at the market, etc. We also had some arranged transfers/cabs that were to be paid locally in cash.
2- I used Omio for 2 of our trains and Italo’s site for the third. All electronic tickets, zero problems with any of the trips.
3- Everybody says there are water fountains everywhere, but we actually had to really look for them at times. That said, I filled my bottle with tap water when needed and that was good, too.
4- If you have any opportunity to stay at the Il Falconiere, do it. Our stay there for the cooking school was the highlight of our trip.
5-I’m not super into museums, so while I saw all the highlights/main attractions, simply getting the skip-the-line, self-guided tour worked well for us at some places.
6- I highly recommend Turtle Tours Rome at Night by Golf Cart tour. Our guide/driver was fantastic. I also highly recommend Discover Tuscany’s day tour to Siena, San Gimignano, winery, Pisa. It was a long day, but it was well-timed and our guide was wonderful.

I’m happy to answer any questions if I can help with your planning!
Pic from our room at Il Falconiere - Under the Tuscan Sun. (No filter - yet, it really does look like a painting!)

I travelled with Trenitalia, several trips across Italy in a mix of economy and business carriages. My mother and I carried a medium-large suitcase each. text:
Vatican —> FCO
We are a group of 4 with a large suitcase each.

1. How easy is it to get a taxi without having to deal with unscrupulous drivers? Can we book the night before?

2. Anyone knows the estimatedआणखी cost for taxi (for 4 with a suitcase each) from Vatican to FCO?

3. Also, would it be faster/less risky by train? We need to be at the airport by 8am on a Monday.

TIA 😌

comments.comment_text: We used Uber

You’ll be so much happier if you each take one small rolling bag. We (4) just did 3 weeks that way with trains and taxis and we had such an easy time. We all felt there were clothes we didn’t even need.

Regardless of cost just book a van through a car service will just make your day way less stressful. Also allow yourself plenty of time in Florence we got stuck behind a garbage truck that was going nowhere fast at all.
We took from Vatican to train station 68€

Most taxis are too small to fit 4 large suitcases. So you could take two taxis. (Which is what I would do.) There are a few larger taxis but they tend to be more costly so you might spend as much on a larger taxi or on a van as you would on two regular size taxis. But if you absolutely have to have one vehicle I’d reserve it in advance somewhere because there aren’t many bigger vehicles.

I myself would not take the train with a large suitcase. It’s slower and stressful. You have to get yourself to the train station carrying your bags even before you board the train so that’s extra time right there. And maneuvering luggage through cobblestone streets is no fun at all so you may need a taxi just to get you to the station. In that case you’ll have the two taxi dilemma anyway, plus the cost of those taxis in addition to the cost of four train tickets. And you have to lug your cases up and down steps into and out of the train car. Then you mention “riskier.” It’s always more risky anywhere to carry luggage on public transportation than on a taxi.

You could always ask your hotel to make your transportation arrangements to the airport for you. They do that often so they usually have arrangements with reliable companies. Or at least ask them for an estimate of the cost. Because they’ll have current, up to date info.

In my opinion money spent on making things easier is money well spent. I think springing for two taxis is the easiest option here. So I’d gladly pay the cost if two taxis to avoid stress.

And in my opinion I think the fear of “unscrupulous” taxi drivers is exaggerated. Taxis fares are regulated by law in Rome. So just be sure you take a white taxi with the official Rome logo on the door. It will have a meter and the drivers license number will be displayed inside along with a telephone number to call in case you suspect wrongdoing. And keep in mind that sometimes tourists mistake things. Tourists at times think a taxi driver is going out of the way in order to boost the fare. But in reality given the maze like nature of the streets in Rome you actually might have to go east to get to the west. And taxi companies keep the drivers updated on congestion so a driver may very well take what seems to be a roundabout way to get around a traffic jam instead of driving into a back up. It’s a shame when an effort to keep the fare down results in an oblivious tourist accusing the driver of deception!

So I’d say that in general you don’t have to worry too much about the taxis if you take an official taxi.
I think it’s posted on the door. 50. Euros.

We were waiting for him at the pick up point. I tried to rebook 5 more times and they would accept the reservation then cancelled. We ended up walking in the 97 degree heat because the waiting line to get a Taxi was so long by then. Luckily after walking for 10 or 15 minutes we walked by a Taxi Stand and was able to get one to take us to Airb&b.
However, we have no issue with using FreeNow App to book ride from our Airb&b to the Vatican or to the airport. So if use FreeNow App, have an alternative plan in case they cancel on you.
We were spoiled in Greece, our Airb&b host booked our taxi for us at the airport.
Our Airb&b host in Rome was not as helpful. She recommended the taxi App when I asked her to book a taxi for us. 😂
It was our first time navigating transportation in Italy. It was an adventure.

Book with Queen limousine. They will guarantee a driver in a large vehicle that can accommodate your luggage and they will be at the designated spot on time, guaranteed. Price is around 60€ during normal hours for Rome central to FCO or vice versa. You can send them a booking request email and they will respond. 10/10 recommend (we use them often).

Free now is an easy way to get a taxi. I took a taxi to my hotel from the train station, but later I started using the metro and it is much more affordable and goes to all the major sites. It just depends on where you going cause the metro doesn’t go into some areas
We stayed at a hotel about 10 minutes from the airport the night before our early flight and they provided a large SUV I think it was $30 for us!
Allow plenty of time ahead of departure. More than 2 hours. Our preference is to stay by airport at a hotel - they have shuttles to the airport or they can arrange for transportation
Book an Uber 😊

When you use an app to call a taxi in Rome, the meter starts at the end of the acknowledgement
whether the driver is 3 minutes or 30 minutes away.
Rates for taxies to the airports to a hotel in Rome are fixed. It doesn’t matter how many people are in the cab. The fare is a fixed rate.

Never ask a driver how much a ride will be. The minute you do, he will shut off the meter and raise the price.

Never ask a driver if he will accept a credit card beforehand. All are required to do so. If you ask and the drive says no, he is scamming you and the taxi company so he can pocket cash if you are willing to forgo the credit card. Just enter the cab, give your destination address then pay him with either cash or credit card at the end of the ride.

Do not try to flag down a taxi on the street. It is illegal for drivers to pick up fares this way. Find a taxi stand sign ( they are orange black TAXI signs) which are located throughout Rome and wait for a cab. They usually appear within a few minutes as drivers know to frequent fares at these locations.
The bus works well for me with a large check in, not knowing which metro station has an elevator
Uber Black. We used it all over Rome, mostly E-class and Vito Mercs.
Uber works! We used it many times in May and each visit!

I thought the taxi’s in Rome were great , drivers were friendly and the fares were reasonable. Reasonable compared to San Francisco where everything is overpriced and expensive. A 7 euro fare in Rome is a $20 fare in San Francisco 🙉

text: Ok so we won’t drive in Rome. We do want to drive from Rome down to Sorrento. We want to see the Blue Grotto. Any info or suggestions will be appreciated.

comments.comment_text: You absolutely can. I've done it. It requires patience, ability to drive in stressful conditions and focus. The driver will not enjoy the alamfi cost road scenery, but tge passengers will. It saves you a ton of time dealing with public transportation.

Rent a small car as the road is narrow. You may still need to fold in the mirrors when meeting oncoming buses. Get an international driver permit at AAA. Video outside of car at pick up and drop off so you have proof of its condition should issues arise later. If you’re staying in Sorrento, hopefully they have parking available.

We just did that. Rented a car from Rome. Stopped in Naples for pizza, spent four days in Sorrento, drove through the Amalfi coast and are now headed towards the southern point of Italy. We have four kids so we have a minivan and we’ve been fine. We were nervous about the roads, because everyone keeps saying how treacherous they are, but it’s not bad at all. We did the road to Hana in Hawaii last year, which is the most nerve-wracking drive. This is not bad at all and there are tour buses doing it all day long. Go for it you will love it!￼￼
Following. Would love names of rental car cos and specific type of car. I know the roads are sooo narrow there but still need space for luggage
Make sure you get hotels with parking
I would take a train
Blue grotto was not open when we did capri water level too high so check before you go !

I rent a car every time I go (about 30 times): I've never gotten an international driver's license....
Some suggestions: make sure you ask for automatic if you don't want to drive stick on narrow mountain roads. I always rent from Hertz but I'm not saying they're the best. Learn about how to do the tolls on the roads: which lanes to be in so you're able to pay correctly. The highways are wonderful but there are tons of speed traps. We always got our insurance through our AMEX card but Italy is one of 3 countries in the world where AMEX doesn't cover auto insurance in case you dent the car. Don't ask me how I found this out. Some of the gas stations are interesting but you can always find one where someone will pump your gas. Parking spaces are 2" smaller than whatever car you're getting. On two lane highways Italians make a third lane in the middle to pass. It's really fun to drive there until you're in a roundabout. In a crowded city.

text:
Is GET YOUR GUIDE a reliable/
trustworthy site to purchase tickets for tours/entry tickets for Rome, Florence, Pisa, Venice?

comments.comment_text: GYG and Viator are legit travel sites, but they are only the middle man for booking with the actual tour operator and not responsible for any cancelled tours. Always best to book direct if you can.

We had a great experience and didn’t have any cancelled in July. It cut out the middle man and we never had to wait in line for tickets.

As mentioned above, always check where the meeting point is so you don’t waste time. In the case of the colosseum, it was at the opposite end of the forum but they used that to give a tour on the way. It was worth it.

I will be spending 2 days on the Amalfi Coast in September. Anything that is a must do in Positano, Amalfi Town or Ravello?? I have a very short list for each city. So I thought I would check to make sure I’m not missing anything. TIA! 🇮🇹

comments.comment_text: One of these gelatos in Amalfi 👌🏼

There’s a lovely museum just as you enter Ravello on the left. Historical garden and castle.

Amalfi there’s lovely beaches and lots of restaurants to go to. We just did a day trip here.

Positano, a lot of shops but can be very crowded. Make sure you walk down to the coast as you get gorgeous views of the flower arches and churches.

You should definitely visit the Duomo di Amalfi, which is the magnificent cathedral in Amalfi town. The paper museum in Amalfi is also very interesting. There is a long history of paper making in the area. They sell some beautiful stationery products in the gift shop. Ravello is gorgeous, it has some of the best views along the coast. The gardens and villas are the highlight there, definitely visit Villa Rufolo and Villa Cimbrone. Positano is generally very photogenic and pretty, but also very crowded and expensive. There's nothing specific to see/do there except to just wander around the village, window shop, and enjoy the beautiful setting. If you have time, I would highly recommend a day trip by ferry to the island of Capri, it is one of the loveliest places I've ever been to.
boat trip to Capri and ride the chair lift up to top in Anacapri

Don’t forget to hike the trail known as the Path of the Gods - start by getting the local bus from Amalfi to Bomerani, the path stretches between Bomerano and Nocelle, then take the bus or walk down the stone steps (there’s quite a lot of them!) to Positano, it’s magical, not to be missed! Wear good shoes and do it on a clear day.😁
Villa Rufolo and Cimbrone in Ravello. Amalfi cathedral. Skip Positano
